conclusion: Understanding the problem involves two objects A and B moving in the same direction with velocities plotted against time.
A velocity-time graph has velocity on the y-axis and time on the x-axis; the area under the curve gives displacement.
Displacement for A and B can be found by calculating the area under their respective velocity curves.
A's velocity curve is always above B's curve in the interval from 0 to t1.
A has a greater velocity and thus a greater displacement than B at any time t.
The difference in displacement is given by the area between their velocity curves, which is always positive and increasing.
If A's velocity is always greater, the displacement difference should be continuously increasing.
Mathematically, the difference in displacement is the integral of (vA(t) - vB(t)), which is positive.
Even if the velocity difference decreases, as long as vA(t) > vB(t), the displacement difference keeps increasing.
Both curves are parabolic with A having a higher peak than B.
The derivative of the displacement difference is vA(t) - vB(t), which is positive, indicating continuous increase.
Continuously increasing means the difference keeps getting larger over time.
Example with vA(t) = 10 - t^2 and vB(t) = 5 - (t/2)^2 shows vA(t) > vB(t) for all t in [0, t1].
